Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.
PALESTINE - SYRIA LINE.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).
RED SEA LINE.

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.
div.p: LONDON, PARIS ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, AND PORT SAID.
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 18-9-905

div.head: Crand Continental Hotel
div.p: The Viennese- orchestra at the Continental Hotel, Cairo, met with great success at its first concert and it has been decided to give concerts in the bar saloon and grill room nightly from 10 p.m. to 1.80 a.m. and also on Sunday after noons from 5 to 7.

div.head: Coal Imports.
div.p: Between January 1 and November 21, 1,176,488 tons of coal were imported into Egypt, of which 652,775 tons were Welsh, 138,806 Newcastle, 174,201 Yorkshire, 91,513 Seoteh and 119,193 other qualities. During the corresponding period of last year the goal im : ports totalled 1,181,047. :

div.head: The Press Case.
div.p: Count Max di Collatto has issued a very interesting survey of the recent Press Case in Cairo, which aroused such enormous interest during the summer and showed only too clearly that some of the members of the Native Bench in Egypt are swayed by the prejudices of Pan-Islamism. We will review this interest| ing brochure st length in a subsequent issne.

div.head: The Late Hadji Brown.
div.p: A correspondent writes :-"In the "Gazette" of the 15th I observe a sympathetic letter from "Veritas" about the work of my old friend Hadji Brown. The terms of this letter move me to write and say that, if "Veritas" is disposed to disclose himself confidentially, I sball be happy to tell him what I kuow of the old fellow. I faney I was the only friend he had amongst his own countrymen, and I knew him intimately for many years, having a very great regard for him."

div.head: The Stefano Quartette
div.p: The Quartette A. de Stefano who have been delighting the visitors to Shepheard's hotel every evening for the past month, are leaving at the end of the month for Upper Egypt where they are to give instrumental concerts at the principal hotels at Luxor and Assouan. Their departure will be a loss to Cairo, and the conductor is to be complimented upon the success of his orchestra. The harp solos espel cially have been particularly fine and have never failed to elicit a call for an encore,

div.head: Tawfik Paino. Hotel
div.p: We are very pleased to hear that though the Tewfik Palace Hotel has been sold by Dr. Bentley, no alterations will be made this season, pending the decision of the new pro prietors The hotel will be opened on November 27, and will be fun practically on the same lines as in previous seasons. An unusual number of applications for rooms bave been already received and judging from the tarif which appears on our advertisement page we are sure that the new proprietors will have a splendid season. The magnificient private. gardens are one of the chief attractions of Helouan and are already beginning to look their best

div.head: Zizinin Theatre
div.p: The acute financial crisis is having a bad effect on the theatre and not a single box was taken last night at the Zizinis Theatre, while the rest of the house was almost a void. Madame Munte was, as usual, excellent, and her rendering of the heroine of "La Dame aux Camelias" could not have been better. She was well supported by Mr. Joumard as the father and Malle. Germanie Milo as Nanine. Wel cannot commend M. de l'Isle's impersonationi of Armand Daval. The company is leaving for Cairo on Monday, where, we understand, they are giving two performances before leaving Egypt, and in each case a guarantee of -3,000 franes a night has been given. The company has had a very poor time of it at Alex andria, which is very regrettable as it is excellent.

div.head: Arabian Wisdom.
div.p: We have received a copy of Dr. John Wortabet's selections and translations from the Arabic, which he publishes, under the title of "Arabian Wisdom." The work forms part of a series, entitled "The Wisdom of the East," now being published by John Murray, London. The object of the editors is promote a feeling of kinship between East and West. They are confident that a true knowledge of the great! ideals and lofty philosophy of Oriental thought may help to a revival of that true spirit of: charity, which neither despises nor fears the nations of another creed ad colour. Dr. Wortabet's work, which cad be obtained at Diemer's Library, Cairo, is a charning toompendium of Arabic thought and can be gordially recomended as giving & very clear insight into the philosophy of the Oriental mind.

div.head: CASINO SAN STEFANO.
div.p: Demain après-midi grand concert sur la ter rasse, qui promet grâce an beau temps de réunir pas mal de promeneurs. La séance de cinéma tographe qui suivra de 6 à 7 heures aura lieu de même sur la terrasse ou en cas de mauvais temps, dans le café d'hiver. Entrée P.T. 5. Car nets de 25 billets P.T. 75, le secrétariat de livre aussi des abonnements d'hiver, à raison de P.T. 200 pour famille et P. L. 100 abonnement personnel.

div.head:
ADVANTAGE OF FREE TRADE.
SUDAN AS AN EXAMPLE
div.p: LORD CROMER'S OPINION.
(Gazetto's Special Sorvico.)

London, Friday. In his speech at the Unionist Free Trade dinner Lord Cromer said that the condition of the Sudan was an illustration of allowing free trade to be the basis of Imperial policy. The Sudan is neither British nor Egyptian, it is Anglo Egyptian. Foreign Governments might have taken exception to the creation of a hybrid political situation hitherto anknown to international jurists. But no marmar was heard. Why was this? Becanse a special clause was inserted in the convention regulating the future Sudan to the effect that no preference should be given to the trade of any one nation For this no other than the late Lord Salisbury was responsible. Did any one believe we should have obtained general European acceptance of our Egyptian policy if the British commercial poliey had been exclusive. One of the main reasons was that, despite the many difficulties, our success in Egypt was because the principles of free trade had been rigidly applied.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
div.p: On Thursday the Khedive received in private andience Sheikh Abdel Ibn Al Abdelrahman, Chief Cadi of Cairo, Saad Pasha Zagloul, Sheikh Al Bakhry, and Mansfield Pashs
His Highness will return to Alexandria next week for a few days in order to inspect bls Mariont property and will stay at Montazah.

div.head: LIBERAL PARTY FEELING
div.p: On November 9th Mohamed Bey Wahid sent the following telegram to his Majesty King Edward :

"In the name of the committee of the Egyptian Liberal Party now assembled in Helouan to celebrate your Majesty's birthday and of all Liberals in Egypt I humbly beg to offer Your Majesty the expression of our respectful congratulations and earnest prayers that God may grant you a long and happy life and protect Your Great Empire for the good of the many nations living under the auspices of British Justice."
On Thursday Mohamed Bey Wahid received the following reply : -

Sir, I am instructed by His Majesty's Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs to inform you that His Majesty The King duly received the telegram which you addressed to His Majesty on the occasion of his birthday and I am to express to you His Majesty's thanks for this kind message of congratulation.
I am, Sir, Your most obedient, humble servant,
(Signed) Eunos GORST.

div.head: TIBN SHOONAH ON FIRE
div.p: What might have resulted in a serious conflagration broke out at 12 o'clock this morning in the tibn shoonah of Mr. Peel on the Mabmoudieh Canal, Minet el Bassal, the property of Messrs. Sursoek.

The Fire Brigade was very quickly in attendance apon receiving the call, but the difficulty of their task kept them - bard at work for several hours, and even up to the moment of going to press reports are being received that the fire is not entirely extinguished. The building itself has withstood the blaze but a large quantity of its contents have been destroyed, the value of which it is impossible to estimate at the moment of writing.

div.head: EGYPTIAN SELF-TAUGHT."
div.p: This little manual is intended as a practical handbook of colloquial Arabie, as spoken in Egypt, for the Army and Navy, travellers, mis sionaries and traders, in the Nile Valley and Delta, or in the Sudan.

By the use of this book, students, tourists and others will find they are quite competent to make themselves understood by all classes of Arabs met with in Egypt, the Sudan, and a considerable part of North Africa.

Full vocabularies of words in common, every day use are supplied, including a particularly comprehensive list of military terms and a useful section of conversational phrases and sentences of a practical character. In addition an outline of the grammar of Arabie is given, and students of the language will find this of great assistance in mastering the construction of sentences.
In the vocabularies the plural has in most cases been added to the nouns, as well as the imperative of the verbs, which also opcasionally presents difficulties

The system of transliteration adopted is of a simple and phonetic character, and is clearly laid down at the commencement of the book, where the forms of the Arabie characters are given, together with a full explanation of the peculiarities of pronunciation, the Egyptian rendering of the Arabic alphabet, and the equivalent sound of each letter in English thus supplying the key to the second column throughout

Keyptian Self-Tight (Ambie containing Alphabet and Pronunciation -Volares Elementary Grammar Idio matie Phrases and Conventions Travel Talk-Money. Weights and Measure, by Captain C. A. Thim Third Edition, Revised and Enlarged by Major EA. Marriott, D.O. London : Marlborough & Co., 51, Old Balley, K. 1907

div.head:
EGYPTIAN COMPANIES.
CASSA DI SCONTO
div.p: EMIN BEY AZMY'S ACTION, Emin Bey Army, as shareholder in the Cassa di Sconto e di Risparmio, has brought an action against the liquida tors of that bank. The writ of summons which we reproduce below, contains a reference to the report of Messrs. Russell, Kerr and Wyatt. We may mention that this report was compiled at the request of the Syndicate of Bankers, etc., and was handed to the Na tional Bank of Egypt at Alexandria. It was, we are informed, not in any way for the information of the shareholders. As to the report of Mr. Stross, which contains details as to the clients of the bank, etc., the directors thonght that it contained too many delicate details to be communicated to the shareholders.
The writ of summons runs as follows:

"D'avoir dans les dix jours de la signification des présentes à faire paraitre dans les journaux d'Alexandrie et du Caire, chargés de insertions légales, les avis convoquant indistincte ment tous les actionnaires de la Cassa di Soonto e di Risparmio, à une Assemblée Générale qui sera tenue dans le courant du mois de décembre prochain, à l'ancien siège de la Société pour discuter et délibérer sur l'ordre du jour suivant:
I. Rapport des liquidateurs sur la liquidation course à partir du 2 juillet dernier avec états de la situation.

II. Nomination d'une commission composée de trois ou d'un plas grand nombre de membres, avec mission de s'adjoindre aux liquidateurs en fonctions aux fins d'examiner de concert, d'après les livres, régistres et documents de la Société :

A. Si la nouvelle émission du 11 mars 1907 a été ordonnée par le Conseil d'Administration dans des conditions normales, ou si cette nouvelle émission n'a été qu'un moyen déguisé pour faire rentrer de nouvelles sommes d'argent dans les caisses d'une société dont la situation, loin de correspondre aux déclarations faites par le Conseil d'Administration en son rapport à l'Assemblée Générale du 17 mars 1907 était des alors fortement compromise

B. Si la liquidation prononcée le 2 juillet 1907 après la fermeture des guichets adverine le 21 juin 1907 dite liquidation ayant en vue de conjurer la faillite inévitable, n'a pas été la conséquence des fautes et des erreurs de toute nature, commises par l'administrateur délégué, fautes lourdes et erreurs entralnant la responsabilité du Conseil d'Administration, qui, au lieu de surveiller et de controler, n'a fait preuve que d'une inconcevable et coupable négligence.
III. Communication da Rapport de Russell, Kerr et Wyatt dont l'Assemblée Générale du 2 Juillet 1907 n'a pas eu connaissance.
IV. Communication da Rapport du 11 Juin 1907, de M.A. Stross soumis à ses collègues du Conseil d'Administration dit Rapport froit d'un réveil tardif."

div.head: CORPORATION OF WESTERN EGYPT
div.p: The Corporation of Western Egypt, Ltd., announces that in connection with the Western Oases Railway all contractors' work on the descent into the oasis is now finished, together with formation work in the oasis. The only task remaining is platelaying in the oasis to Khargeh Town, which is now in progress. The passenger coaches, which were shipped whole, have been delivered and everything is anticipated to be in readiness within the next month for the official opening of the line, which is now engaging the attention of the directors. The well last finished has given a flow of upwards of 380 gallons per minute and further applios tions for land continue to be received. The average picking per feddan of the largest of the experimental cotton crops gave the satisfactory result of 1,391,4 lbs, being for these new lands a return but little short of the average Delta erop. Further and remunerative busis ness for the supply of stone to the Nile Valley is in prospect

div.head: SIDI SALEM ESTATES LTD.
div.p: The Parquet is still investigating the theft of £2,300 from the office of the Sidi Salem Estate Limited at Sidi Salem near Kafr Sheikh

div.head: EGYPTIAN AND SYRIAN LAND CO.
div.p: The Egyptian and Syrian Land Company Limited has just purchased three fine buildings in Tewfik Pasha Street, Alexandria, trom Mr. Dumani, the Syrian capitalist for LE. 36,000.

div.head: NEW EGYPTIAN CO
div.p: Some shareholders of the New Egyptian Company Limited, who are annoyed at the downward tendency of the shares of this company, are endeavouring to combine in order to induce the board of directors to set forth the exact position of affairs. A meeting of shareholders is to be summoned shortly and will be held at the offices of the International Chamber of Commerce at Cairo. The "ordre du jour" is as follows :
"Nomination d'une commission d'actionnaires chargée de demander aux représentants en Egypte et, si nécessaire, Londres, de la New-Egyptian Cy. Ltd. Is situation de la la Société
"Propositions diverses."

div.head: CALLS AND COMPANIES
div.p: To EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Sir, --I cordially appreciate the good sense of your correspondent's remarks under the above heading in your issue of today. The publie throughout Egypt has entirely lost confidence and when we have seen the condition of affairs in some of the older companies, it is not likely that the public will be eager to pay up calls in the companies started last season. No companies should ask for further calls under present oireumstances nntil after their first financial year's working and the balance has been published. It can then be seen how much is in arrear in regard to calls and whether the company is seriously embarassed thereby. If the shareholders see that the pay. ing up of their shares will be of material assistance to the Company, they will then come foreward, but until then few will veuture to throw good money after bad, as your correspondent says
Truly yours
"FAIR PLAY." Alexandria, 22nd November.

div.head: SIR DRUMMOND HAY.
div.p: To The EDITOR OF Tux "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Dear Sir, I should be much obliged, if you would give me this opportunity of correcting one or two inaccuracies, which appeared in the artiola -entitled, "Notes from Beyrout," of Tuesday, November 19th.
Your correspondent mentioned the coming departure of Sir R. Hay Drummond Hay, and it is on this subject that he made some mis statements.

It is true that after more than a dozen years' service in Beyrout that the Consul General is shortly retiring and leaving the country, but he has no intention of going to end his days," as your correspondent somewhat gruesomely puts it, in England. Sir Robert has lately bought a house at Torquay, but he has also a large estate near Tangier, in Morocco, whither he will also paiss some of his time. It is also far from Sir Robert's ides to retire from pablic life, and there is no ground for supposing that because he is leaving his post at Beyrout be will not be entrusted with other dnties, for which he will be peculiarly fitted owing to his long experience in Government service.
Yours faithfully E. C. DONALDSON RAWLINS. HM's Aeting Vice Consal.
Beyrout H.B.M.'. Consulate General
Beyrout, November 19.

div.head: PRESENT DAY LUXOR.
div.p: To The EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Sir, ---It is many years since I visited Luxor and in spite of the marvellous temples, relies of the past, my recollection was of a fatiguing journey, a dirty town, and a hot, airless hotel. In the delight I am experiencing in the reverse of all this I cannot help putting pen to paper that other weary Cairenes may experience the same pleasure I have travelled as much as almost any man living but, I can frankly say I have never had so easy and luxurions a 13 hours journey a the Wagons Lits supply to Luxor and Assouan; but the change from old conditions is still more mark ed in the delightful cool and health hotel on the banks of the Nile. It is impossible to imagine a more perfect atmosphere or more peace ful general surroundings. Today I visited the market as I have done in former times. Instead of a veritable Babel all was orderly and well arranged in a market place of twice the size. The Bicharins, with their extraordinary curled hair, with their leather goods in one corner, the animals of all kinds in separate places and well exposed for sale, whereas formerly it was almost impossible to get near what you wanted to buy The village also is clean and sanitary, in great contrast to the odoriterous and dangerous streets of Cairo. If the railway prove equal to the provision of sufficient cars, I venture to predict that hundreds will, one day not far distant, make week end trips to Laxor for a delightful change of air and scene. Your constant reader
VIATOR. Luxor Winter Palace, November 21.

div.head: HEBREW RECORDS AT ASSOUAN.
div.p: The expedition to Assouan last winter of M. Clermont Ganneau, on behalf of the French Academy, to obtain the Hebrew papyri supposed to be there on the site of the ancient Elephantine, has several times been reported in our columns as well as the fact that, so far as the manuscripts were concerned, the search was successful. It now appears that Germany had obtained the desired documents, and a first instalment of their contents has been edited by Dr. Sachau, of Berlin. Three of them are now published, two of which are, with bat slight variations, duplicates, and these papyri are of most exceptional interest, for they refer to several personages mentioned as taking prominent part in the historie events described in the Book of Nehemiah. The chief persons thus referred to are Sanballat and Johanan. The two papyri preserve counterparts of a petition to Bagons, governor of Judah, for permission to restore the Jewish temple to Yahu (Jehovah) at Elephantine, which during the absence of the governor Arsam, (appointed by Darius, who had probably gone to Persis) had been destroyed by the Egyptians who were worshippers of the God of the Catarnet. This Arsam, or Arames, is mentioned as Satrap of Egypt, by Ctesias. The confirmation of the historical accuracy of Nebemish by means of paytyri discovered in Egypt is one of the most remarkable events in the whole history of Egyptian exploration. There are, however, in Berlin other AramaioHebrew papyri from the same site, and further most important results both for philology, and history will yet be disclosed.

div.head:
PORT SUDAN.
THE HARBOUR
div.p: Port Sudan was selected as the terminus of e railways and as the port of the Sudan wing to the great difficulties connected with

approach to Soakim. Some critics still ursist in their opinion that it would have been ser to have kept to the latter port, but all e experts are against them. The disadvanta * of Suskim are great. There is no entrance the port at night and, if it had been thought Ivisable to endeavour to make such an entry ssible, the cost of lighting would have been normous. It is estimated that to make the orth approach to Suakim practicable by night
least eleven lights would be necessary, and hen then it is very doubtful if ships would ak it. On the other hand the approaches to ort Sudan are as easy as those of any port
the world and the proof that they do ot present the slightest difficulty is evi.
need from the fact that not a single misap has as yet occurred. Its harbour is the mest between Malts and Bombey. Moreover
is an ideal place for a naval base and a hole fleet of men-of-war could be accommodat
with ense. It also possesses great strategie Avantages, for if the Suez Canal were blocked
time of war, it would be easy to send troops • India by way of Alexandria, the Nile, and ort Sudan. .

THE HARBOUR INLET. A straight channel with deep water gives an may access to the mouth of the harbour. he mouth lies at « slight angle to the 1 eneral trend of the const so that the efs outside form a shelter from the heavy As brought in by Foutherly and ensterly inds. The entry is about five hundred yards ride, and this breadth continues for nearly a mile Then the inletexpands into a basin on the buth side, which is some nine hundred yards ong by five hundred yards broad, having a minimum depth of six fathoms. Beyond this the channel runs up into the land for

distance of about two miles. There is another asin on the north side about one and a balt miles up, and a third at the end of the inlet. For one mile after leaving the first basin the rater hasa minimum depth the whole way up to wo and three quarter fathoms. The narrowest art of the inlet is about seventy yards. The hores, of .coral, rise to a height of from six o fourteen feet above sea level.

THE MAKING OF THE PORT. The first two berths in Port Sudan will robably be finished by next March. The new blocks are up to sea level for over a undred metres. The first contract is for six undred metres of berths to berth five ships. Five electric cranes are ready for work. The monstruction of four coal unloaders and four ransporters has just started. They will be orked by electric power. The power station almost finished and the machinery is on

way out from England. The dockyard rorkshops and smiths shops have been comleted and the machinery is nearly all in posiion. A steel vertical swing bridge crosses the arbour about one mile from the month. It was nished two months ago The bridge was contracted by the Cleveland Bridge and Engineer ng Company of Newcastle on Tyne who are also atting up the coal transporter. It is a single pan, allowing one hundred and eighty feet of airway with unlimited water. Two slips are to
built at once in the inner harbour, The arlour is traversed by ferry boats, which are Il licensed and tariffed.
The question of fortifying the harbour has jot yet been decided upon. The administra ion of the Harbours and Lights is under the apable direction of Kaimakan Drory Bey, R. assisted by Captain Draper.

AS A COALING STATION. There is likelihood that Port Sudan may soome a coaling station of some importance. Now ships for the Far East have to coal at both Port Said and Colombo. Port Sudan, which is even hundred miles from Suer, would, if used
a coaling station, permit of these ships only baling once there instead of at these two orts.

The Government coalyard is under contruction. At present the railway coal goes to Joakim, but when the railway terminal headquarters have finished moving to Port Sudan, il the railway coal will come there. Plots for paling sites have been selected for the use of private firms for coaling.
AS A PORT OF CALL The following lines call regularly :The Khedivial Mail Line's express mail ervice in connection with the Brindisi mail rom Suer, every week.
The Khedivial Mail Line's Aden steamers, ortnightly.
The British East African Line (The Dale ane), once every three weeks or fortnightly. Inch of these ships have averaged from three

four thousand tons per ship to Port Badan ind Suskim of general goods and construction material for Port Sudan and south of Kbarpom. Some bring cargo for the Congo Free State via Khartoum. Or this average of three to bar thousand tons about fifteen hundred tons o to Suskim for railway material.
The Rotterdam Lloyd stenmers, once every ix weeks, bringing construction material.
The Hamburg American Live to the Persian Ralf, once every four weeks.
The Porto-Rabattino Line intend, it is said, alling at Port Sudan on their way to Mas yowah from next April. These steamers would all both outwards and homewards
The steamers of the British India, Bueknalls ind the Strick Lines call occasionally on the way out.

THE FUTURE OUTLOOK. The advantages of such splendid natural tharbour, having a depth of from twenty to twelve fathoms for at least two kilometres, are obvious. A man-of-warof the "Dreadnought" class could come in at any time and turn easily. Now ships of seven thousand tons some alongide the temporary quay with pontoons without the slightest difficulty. Every effort is being made to furnish the port with all the latest improvements in order to induce ships to come there, but it must be ponfessed, that great deal of the shipping that has hitherto called there, will care in. the near future when the great Government works no longer demand a constant supply of engineering and other material from Berope. The port will have to wait patiently for wears to come while the Sodan slowly de welops. Even then it will never be more than
forwarding port after the Newhaven type. The problem of the future outlook will be Healt with more fully in another article on the trade of the Port.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: The illness of the Heir Apparent to the Khediviate was, we understand, much more erious than is generally supposed. Indeed here was a period when his life was in danger. Both children are getting on well now and, as ar as can be judged, will soon be completely restored to health. It is supposed that in both mstandes typhoid was contracted from eating un peeled frait
Mr. Montagn Summers, the late Managing Director of the Egyptian Estates Limited, who
now in London, has expressed his intention of returning to Egypt shortly. Mrs. Montagu Hummers will not return here as her health will not permit of her residing in a hot climate.
Hassan Bey Murad has passed the final law xamination at Paris.
HassabBey Hasib, Mudir of Assouan, will hortly be transferred to Minish and Ahmed Bey Kamel, Secretary to Chitty Bey, will be ppointed Mudir of Assouan.
Mr. Hermann Engel, of Vienna, has been ppointed director of the Austro-Orientalischen Handels-Actiengesellschaft for Alexandria.
Canon W. J. Oldfield, late Chaplain at Assouap, has taken the degrees of B.D. and .D. at Oxford by accumulation.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Bllerman liner "City of Venice" arrived at Liverpool last Tuesday morning.
The Ellerman liner "Adalis" miled for Liverpool on the 20th inst." with a full cargo neluding 6223 bales of cotton.
The Ellerman liner "City of Khios miled From Malta on the 19th inst. and is due here with passengers and general cargo this morning.
The Ellerman liner "Britannia" sailed from Liverpool yesterday with general cargo for Gibraltar, Malta and Alexandria.
The Moss liner "Rameses. Arrived at Liver pool yesterday,
The S.S. "British Prince," left London on the 20th inst, and is due to arrive at Alexandria on or about the Tth December..

REDUCED PRICES

div.head:
THE TRANSVAAL ELECTIONS.
PREPONDERANCE OP DUTCH.

div.p: In the elections for the first Parliament for the Orange River Colony the contest is practically confined to Bloemfontein where the constitutional, or British party, has won four seats out of five. The bountry districts are solidly Dutch but the party cleavage between the British and the Dutch is very slight. The nominated council consists of six Datch and five British members

div.head:
THE AMERICAN CRISIS
FRANCE'S REFUSAL OP GOLD.

div.p: A semi-official statement has been made here that the United States approached the French Government a fortnight ago with regard to an advance of 100,000,000 francs in gold from the Bank of France direct. As no natioual issue bank exists in the United States and the Bank of France is unable to accept private paper in exchange for gold, the Government demanded the American Government's own guarantee. As this was not forthcoming there have been no further overtares and any further assistance will be through the Bank of England.
(Router)
Another amount of 2,800,000 dollars of gold has been engaged.
(Renster)

div.head:
AMERICAN WAR MINISTER
RETURN TO NEW YORK.

div.p: It is stated here that Mr. Taft, American War Minister, is obliged on account of pressure of work preparatory to the opening of Congress to hasten his return. For this reason he will abandon the visits he intended making to the Baropean courts and will embark at Hamburg on board the "President Grant" of the Hamburg-Amerika Line
(Router)

div.head:
LIVERPOOL SCHOOL OF TROPICAL MEDICINE.
LORD CROMER VICE-PRESIDENT.

div.p: Lord Cromer has accepted the vice-presideney of the Liverpool School of Tropical Medecine, which was instrumental in freeing Ismailis from malaria.
(Reuter)

An agreemerft has not been arrived at at the conference of spinners and operatives held at Oldham. The notices of 10,000 operatives will expire on Saturday. In the event of the strike being prolonged the spinners will look out other mills, throwing 150,000 people idle.
(Reuter)
The Lower House of the Hungarian Diet has unanimously authorised enforcement of the Ausgleich from 1st January, the question of apportionment of the common expenditure excepted.
(Reuter)

It is stated that the disagreement between King Leopold and the Government regarding the taking over of the Congo has been adjusted and that the treaty of annexation will be laid before the Chamber next week. (Reuter)
Count Benckendorft has received the Grand Cross of the Victorian Order. (Reuter)
The civil marriage of Prince George of Greece has been celebrated at Pasay. (Havas)
The Dams has unanimously voted an address of loyalty to the Tsar.
(Haras)
At the conclusion of the sitting of the Chamber it was announced that M. Abramovies, ex chief of the Polish Club, replaces M. Dsieduseki as Minister of Galicia. (Havas)
The Nasi trial has been adjoumed until December 3. The newspapers believe that the Chamber, which meets on Thursday, will intervene.
(Hanas)
The political situation is growing worse.
(Haras)
The railway strike is ended. (Reuter)
The "Mauretania" arrived this morning. She was hampered by storm and fog. (Reuter)
A Russian special correspondent despatched Karatagh confirms that 10,000 deaths have aken place.
(Reuter)
Cricket.M.C.C. 289 runs for 9 wickets.
(Reuter)

div.head: EGYPT EXPLORATION FUNI
div.p: NO EXPEDITION THIS WINTER
VALUABLE FINDS AT OXYRHYNCHU
attendance.
Mr. P. G. Hilton Price, F.S.A., presided the twenty-first annual meeting of the Egy Exploration Fund, held at Burlington Hou Piccadilly, on Tuesday week. There was a la

The Hon. Treasurer, Mr. Grueber, in 1 statement on the financial position of t Pund, referred to the completion of Dr Navill long and arduous work at Deir el-Bahari. had, he said, been a stupendous task, and o with which the name of the Egypt Explorati Fund will in future for ever be associated. T final completion of the clearing of this site due to the munificent donation of £1,000 fro Mr. W. M. Laffan, of New York Dr. Grenf and Dr. Hunt had also brought to a close the labours at Behiness, and they were of opinii that they had thoronghly explored that distric

The total expenditure in the case of the E ploration Fund during the past year had be £2.279 :1: 2., as against £1,922 : 19:6. in t previous year. The actual cost of the expec tion was £1,898:13:10, of which sum £1,15:3: was provided by the Laffan Fund. The amou paid in wages for workmen exceeded that any previous occasion, owing to the labour co nected with the clearing of the site before les ing.

The General Balance Sheet showed that th assets of the Pand and its branches amount on the 31st July last to £2908 11s 8d, against £8691 16s. 6d. last year, but this la sam included the Laffan Fund of £1,00 These assets are apportioned as follows -1 the Egypt Exploration Fund, £1,675 3s. 8d. to the Archaeological Survey, £797 8s. Id and to the Greco-Roman Branch, £383 198. 11

Owing to the present low state of the finance the committee had decided to postpone th operations at Abydos until 1908-9. This wa the first year since its foundation that th Fand had not sent out an expedition, and was with great reluctance the committee adop ed this course.

In conclusion Mr. Grueber proposed a vot of congratulation to M. Naville on the compl tion of his great work at Deir el-Bahar which had occupied him 14 years, his service during that time being given gratis, and thanks for his valuable labours. He couple with the motion the name of Madame Naville who had been associated throughout in th work, and who had supplied many beautifu and artistic plates to the memoirs.

The resolution was carried with acclamation The Hon. Treasurer's report and balance shee was adopted on the motion of Mr. Joseph of ford, who expresed satisfaction that the Ame rican subscriptions to the Fund had been ang mented, and the hope that these would con tinue to increase

The President followed with an exhaustiv account of the operations connected with the various branches during the past year. In th course of his address he mentioned that Mr Weigall had made a detailed inspection of the country as far south as the Sudan frontier Amongst other things, he had located the tribe who buried their dead in the "Pon Graves, which would be of interest to many. He found the cartouches of Kings Kames and "Aahines of the XVIIth Dynasties, near Abu Simbel proving that they were were not the pett: princes of Thebes which they been thought t have been. He also located a hitherto unknown temple and fortress at Anaybeh, and foun cartouches of unknown kings of the Middl Kingdom.

Mahmud Effendi Rushdy had been appoint ed inspector for the district from Aswant the Sudan frontier. He had been for severa years secretary to Mr. Weigall. At Aswan M Weigall spent some time in renumbering th hundreds of rock inscriptions, which were i danger of being quarried by mistake. Mi Frice referred to Mr. Davis's discovery of th tomb of Queen Tais as one of the most enter taining events of the year in Egyptology. H said that Dr. Elliot Smith had come to the con clusion that the bones found were those of young man not more than 26 years of age, an Mr. Weigall, who knew the facts of the di covery, led to suppose that they were those Akhenaten himself. If so, since Akhenate reached the seventeenth year of his reign, could not have been more than ten years ol when he began to reign. In the fourth year already had one daughter; the Aten heres was then in full vigour, El Amarna, was bein built, and Thebes was probably abandoned the Court. It was hardly conceivable that snc great revolations, religious and political, took place in Egypt at that time could has been effected by a boy of thirteen or fourtee years old. Mr. Price, did not, therefore, conside they could accept this theory until some furth sorroborative evidence had been produced.

Mr. Naville's address on his work at Dein al-Bahari was read by Mr. H.R. Hall, in D Naville's absence. He thanked the committe for having gone on to the end with the excav tions, and for having entrated him with th direction of the operations. He also expresse his gratitude to his numerous fellow-worker without whose valuable assistance it woul have been impossible for him to accomplis that long and sometimes arduous task. vould safely appeal to those members of th wadience who had seen Deir el-Bahari ini present state to testify that the money had no
een spent in vain, and that the final result wa vell worth the labour and expense it had cos

Dr. Grenfell then gave an interesting accour f the excavation which he and Dr. Hunt has arried out at Oxyrhynchus. They were h aid able without difficulty to complete th learance of the few remaining mounds whic ontained Greek papyri.
tn bdo inbuild Whiol baik boon for the me art dag in the preceding season, they made ery good find of literary fragments, belongi
the library largely composed of Greek lyi beta (Sapphs, Bacchyildas, Cercidas * hers), of which he spoke last year.
Dr. Grenfell announood that part V. oft Dxyrhynchus Papyri" will be published ne onth. Besides the Odes of Pindar, it co ined only three texts : the vellam fragma

an uncanonical gospel, which would also sued in a cheap edition uniform with t ayings of Jesus; a papyras containing abo sif the Symposium of Plato ; and anoth ontaining considerable portions of the Pan Vrious of Isocrates.

Dr. Greufell then quoted a translation art of a new ode by Pindar in praise of t simple life" written for the inbabitants of t ttle island of Ceos, the home of many poe ad athletes, but which aspired to no politie istinction.

Another find of even greater importance w papyrus containing 800 lines of an unknow reek writer, whom Dr. Grenfell believes to ne fourth-centary historian, Theopompus. ** an annalist, who based his method on the

Thucydides, though his style more close nsembles that of Polybius. The fragmen applies new facts concerning the events 996-5 B.C. and the Constitution of Beotis, an grows valuable light upon the sources, oth ban Xenophon, available to the later histor ms. Dr. Grenfell, indeed, claimed that th
w discovery revealed, if only for a brie riod, the existence of a new and unexpecte car in the firmament of Greek literature.

In addition to these, Oxyrynchus also yielde ome 300 lines of the lost tragedy of Euripide alled Hypsipyle. These lines are scattere ther widely over the play, which containe all about 1,700. Hypsipyle was a dauglita
Thoas, King of Lemnos, and bad snove a in saving her father's life when the wome

the island killed all the men, When her des as discovered she was banished, and becam me nurse of the infant son of Burydice wife yourgus, King of Nemes. The expedition of th ven heroes against Thebes occurred at thi me, and on passing through the territory

yourgus the seer Amphiaraus, who was one me expedition, met Hypsipyle, and requeste er to show them a pare spring of water to b sed in some sacrificial rites. The arrivalo mphiaraus and the meeting with Hypsipyl re narrated in one of the more complete por ons of the papyrus. Hypsipyle consents, and atting down the child of which she was in arge, proveeds to show the way to the water at in her absence the child was bitten by ake and died, the occurrence being narrate
a speech of a messenger, of which a smal gment survives. Hypsipyle, fearful of the ger of the Queen, in a conversation with mphiaratıs (partially preserved) announce

intention of flight. She was, however ptred and condemned to death, the Queen urydice scousing her of having intention ly caused the death of her son. Hypsipyl otests her innocence, but is being led of her doom, when Amphiaraous appear
the scene. He explains to Eurydio hat had sctually happened, and persuade

that che death of her child was an unfon nate accident. He also apparently bring out the recognition of Hypsipyle and he o sons, who had mesnwhile arrived and had en received by Eurydice in ignorance Bir identity. The latter portion of this soen recognition is also in good preservation, an e piece concludes with the appearance of the d Dionysus, from whom Hypsipyle wa scended. The papyrus thus establishes wit fficient clearness the structure of the play d amid a number of small and useless frag ents contains some connected passages asiderable length, including about sevent les of lyrios, apart from those in the scen tween Hypsipyle and her sons, in whicl rical verses are interspersed with iambies bese passages, said Dr. Grenfell, are thon ghly worthy of the poet, and in places ar arked by much beauty and dramatio foro to find is an addition of real value to th mains of Greek tragedy. Besides the Eurip

and several omer classical fragments, th pyri also yielded portions of the lost Gree iginal of the Acts of Peter, which is extar ly in Latin, and of an unknown versionActs of John. This recounts an attemp prevent the apostle from crossing a bridge miraculous disappearance of the obstrue and the subsequent prayer offered up b John.

div.head: REVUE COMMERCIALE
div.p: Coton Nous avions promis dans notre précédente revue, de dire deux mots au sujet des cours des filés en Angleterre pour les 60 twist et nous nous exécutons. L'observation qu'on nous a faite est juste et la comparaison entre Octobre 1906 et Oetobre 1907 est toute en faveur de ce dernier. Seulement, l'année passée la hausse s'est accentuée par la suite, tandis que l'on ne saurait dire ce qui nous attend cette année. En tous cas, si la filature anglaise maintient ses cours pour ces filés, achète-t-elle le coton sur sette base ? Non, il est certain que seals ses engagements à longue baleine peuvent lui per mettre d'afficher ces exigences, comme il n'en est pas moins certain que pour les affaires de quelque importanee, elle ne refuse pas les con cessions,

Quant aux cours du Sea Island, rien de plus trompeur que de les comparer avec ceux d'Oe tobre 1906. L'année derrière la récolte était déficitaire et la hausse n'a battu són plein sur ce coton que beaucoup plus tard et, par conséquent, pour l'année courante, qui comme quantité se trouve être dans le cas opposé à la précédente, le point de départ pour la comparaison devrait être le maximum de 1906-1907, d'autant plus que le retour un niveau normal pour ce genre de coton ne peut être que graduel, au fur et à mesure du developpement des recettes
Ceci dit, passons à notre revue du marché.

Comme faits nouveaux et locaux ayant pu influencer le marché ou intéresser ceux qui s'occupent de coton, nous n'en avons eu ancon, le seul point saillant à relever consistant dans les ventes des haussiers, quand les nouvelles du dehors leur ont para peu encourageantes, et leur rentrée dans l'article dès qu'une dépêche inflammatoire est venue "les faire changer d'avis. On peut done dire que, comme impor tance de positions, il n'y a rien de pouveau.

Par contre, pour ce qui est de l'allure du mar ché, le cas est absolument différent: la fai blesse a dominé en plein et avec le désir intense de réaliser qui existe, la tendance reste des plus hésitantes. Et cette attitude se comprend, car les nouveaux acheteurs, pour soulager les anciens font défaut et ce n'est pas en faisant faire à leurs portefeuilles respectifs la navette entre eux, que les détenteurs de contrats parviendront à se débarrasser de leur coton 1 Bref, au cours auquel le Novembre a été enterré ce soir, la baisse s'élève à 1/2 tallari plein pour la semaine.
Il est vrai que le Janvier ne perd que 3/8, mais cela tient simplement à l'élargissement da report qui, comme nous n'avons cessé de le dire, est toujours la prenve inco estable de la
faiblesse du haussier. Ne désespérons done pas . de voir bientôt le Janvier prendre la place du Novembre

Cela viendra fatalement du reste, car ni da coté de la filature, comme demande, ni de la part du commerce, comme dispositions, ni au point de vue de la crise financière, il n'y a la moindre amélioration à constater. C'est malheureux à dire, mais ce sont là des faits réels !!

Le Novembre 1908 fait parler un peu plus souvent de lui, mais les transactious n'ont guère l'air d'y être plus fréquentes. En tous cas, il maintient sa forte prime sur la récolte actuelle et la dernière cote a été de 19 15/16.

Les nouvelles d'Amérique qui sont venues pendant la semaine stimuler en passant notre marché sont au nombre de trois : La première consiste dans l'annonce des mesures financières que le Gouvernement des Etats-Unis se propose de prendre sous forme d'émission de Bons du Trésor pour enrayer la crise régnante Ix-bas. Mais, au dire des dernières dépêches elles sont considérées comme inefficaces, on pour le moins insuffisantes pour atteindre le but visé.

Quant à la seconde, c'est l'estimation de la récolte par MM. Neill Brothers à 11,600,000 Belles et qui a permis à Price, lequel a tourné casaque depuis quelques jours, de dire que la consommation aurait besoin de 12 500,000 Balles. En face de la généralité des autres autorités qui sont pour 12 1 2 millions, Neill semble trop pessimiste, tandis que Price qui ne fait que répéter une opinion exprimée par Ellison il y a deux mois, serait embarrassé pour prouver qu'après les changements survenus et qui ne sont pas pour le mieux, la consommation pourrait toujours absorber la quantité en question. La situation de l'industrie cotonière en Amérique, comme nous l'avons sighalée tout der nièrement, n'est guère florissante pour le moment, et si la filature en Allemagne, en Aatriche et pent être encore en Italie, a des engagernents à longue haleine, il n'en est pas moine vrai aussi que les stocks invisibles, cela est désormais certain, sont beaucoup plus forts qu'on ne le croyait. La spéculation peut inventer ce qu'elle veut, cela ne change pas la réalité, et par conséquent la propagande que l'on est en train de faire n'a pas l'air de pouvoir aller loin. La crise prime tout actuellement.

La troisième et dernière nouvelle d'Amérique, est le rapport de l'Egrenage au 14 Novem bre, nous donnant le chiffre de 7.811.000 Balles, contre 8.531.000. La différence est trop torte, et quoique la question monétaire y entre pour beaucoup, il n'en est pas moine vrai qu'elle est de nature à ébranler les convictions les plus enracinées quant à ce qui regarde l'importance de la récolte. Seulement, si le dit rapport a induit le de couvert en Amérique à se racheter, son effet sur le marché se réduit à fort peu de chose. . .

Ce n'est donc pas à tort que l'on voit dans ce fait on manque de spéculation, qui s'explique d'ailleurs très facilement dans l'état présent des choses en Amérique et en Europe. On ne guérit pas une plaie comme celle qui existe en Amérique dans les 24 heures et toute personne sensée ne peut que dire qu'il nous faudra peut être plusieurs mois avant qu'un Tetour à une situation normale soit possible.

Manchester se plaint du manque de demande pour l'exportation et sur ce point tout le monde semble d'accord. L'effet des récoltes manquées et de la cherte de l'argent se fait déjà sentir. En tous cas, le comencement de grève à Oldham à la suite de la décision des filateurs, est un indice peu favorable aux cotons égyptiens, car c'est dans le compartiment des filés fins que cela se passe

Ajoutons encore que la spéculation ici met en circulation toutes sortes d'inventions pour réveiller les acheteurs et va jusqu'à parler des possibilités qui pourraient survenir en été, etc. éte. Au lieu d'aller si loin et de spéculer à 8 mois de date, elle ferait plus saine besogne en se limitant à l'immédiat et en faisant plus de cas de ce que nous avons sous les yeur. Certes, les ristournes signalés ne sont pas importants, mais ils n'en constituent pas moins un indice à prendre en considération.

Et puis pourquoi oublier si vite la période Décembre Janvier qui est toujours pen propice " aux affaires, et surtout que de la question du Mit Affifi il n'y a pas grand parti à tirer : le coton fin sera rare et commandera peut-être des prix exceptionnels ou relativement élevés, comparativement au reste, mais les classements livrables contre contrats seront toujours abondants. On ne nous soutiendra pas que le Good Fair Affifi, et au besoin Haute-Egypte, nous manqueront éventuellement pour ce but, sur tout que la valeur de ces qualités est réglée par celle des américains !
Le marché du disponible est calme et la demande depuis deux ou trois jours porte pour ainsi dire seulement sur les cotons fins. Les qualités courantes et les Harte-Egypte sont négligées.

Sous le rapport des prix, il y a irrégularité et tandis que les Affifi ne présentent qu'une petite variation en moins pour le Good fair, les provenances Haute-Egypte reculent de 1/8" pour le fully fair et de 1/4 pour les antres clas sements. Les variétés ont subi des fluctuations diverses, suivant la rareté ou l'abondance; aussi ces baisses et ces baisses limitées n'ont elles auenne signification au point de vue du marché.P
Le mouvement de la récolte, à 50000 cantar près en plus, marche de concert avec celui de l'année dernière.
Contrairement à ce que l'on préconisait, les exportations de la semaine ont fini par atteindre le total de l'année dernière, soit Balles 32000. Nons avions raison de donter de las diminntion

Pour la semaine prochaine, on parle de nouveau de réduction, mais nous ne croyons à ancune diminution sérieuse de ce chef avant le mois de Décembre. L'année papée, la période correspondante a été de 28000 Balles.

Liverpool n'a pas été très chaud pour les égyptiens dispouibles, mais sous le rapport des prix aussi il n'y a aucun changement à relever, la cote restant à 10 1/8 pour le spot et 9 43/64 pour les futurs Janvier

Les américains, par contre, ont eu un marché assez favorable, surtout pour ce qui regarde les prix, qui finissent à 6.00 pour le spot, 5.66 pour le Janvier Février et 5.69 pour le Mars Avril, soit respeetivement 13, 11 et 18 points de hausse.
Graines de coton Les recettes ont été fortes ; mais les grosses exportations ont tout absorbé et la semaine finit ferme pour le disponible à P.T 70.
Pour la semaine prochaine on s'attend à un ralentissement dans les embarquements et les probabilités sont done pour un peu de calme sur les prix

Eu contrats, il n'y a que des affaires occasionnelles. En tous cas, les cours de maintien nent relativement ferme et la dernire cote est de P.T. 73 1/4 pour les trois mois et de P.T. 75.25 pour le janvier-février.
Hull est calme, mais soutenu au cours de de 6 16/3 à 6 17/6.
Le continent nous achète beaucoup de graines cette année.
Tourteaux et huiles sont faibles.

div.head: CHRONIQUE FINANCIERE
div.p: LA SEMAIN Comme nous le faisions entrevoir dans notre dernière chronique financière, la tenue de lundi a été d'une lourdeur caractéristique. Et ce n'était pas un de ces msroles indécis oh les avis sont partagés, non, tout le monde était d'accord pour reconnaitre l'affluence des vendeurs et l'absence de contreparties. La mau vaise homeur provenait sans doute de la baussa du taux privé d'escompte à 1% ainsi que de l'augmentation du taux d'intérêt local et de l'éloignement croissant de l'épargne et du esh pital pour des valeurs qui ne lui occasionnent depuis longtemps que des déceptions. Les af faires ont été presque nulles et la cole a subi une dépression sur la plupart des titres abordas. Contrairement aux journées précédentes, Is | spéculation n'a pas réussi à concentrer l'at: tention sur ses groupes favoris.

p.hi: Le lendemain des intéressés ayantisépaudu le bruit, fondé ou non, que des agences avaient spéculé sur les dossiers de leurs clients et que sur la demande de ceux-ci elles devraient éventuellement se couvrir à n'importe quel prix, on a légèrement repris, en particulier sur les petites valeurs favorites. L'Agricole et la Na I tional Bank, stimulées par un relèvement ad Stock Exchange, ont également bénéficie d'une plus-value. Cependant les efforts tentés pour l. animer la place n'ont pas abouti de cause dų désintéressement général des affaires. La plus part des courtiers étant arrivés ce jour la dans la corbeille sans ordres de vente ou d'achat, sel sont retirés avant la clôture ou sont restés assis sur la maps, spectacle qu'on a pu contempler durant plus d'une heure.

div.p: Mercredi notre marchó a été comme la veille privé de tout intérêt transactionnel. Les rares échanges qui ont eu lieu se sont limités à un petit groupe de valeurs : National Bank, Agricole, Comptoir, Estates, Investuent et Gabbari Land. Mais il n'en a pas été de même des fluctuations de la cote qui ont été nombreuses et ont dénoté une reprise | partielle plus ou moins sensible, attribuée al un retour de confiance dans les affaires américaines et à l'accentuation de la fermeté au Stock Exchange qui en a été la conséqhence. Cette dernière hypothèse est d'autant plas plausible que ce sont nos valeurs dirigeantes cotées à Londres qui ont principalement profite de l'amélioration, tandis que pour nos titres d'ordre secondaire ou purement local le mouve ment a été loin d'être uniforme, quelques-uns continuant à perdre da terrain.

Hier et aujourd'hui la nullité des séances & | éte absolue sous tous les rapports. C'est à peine si quelques affaires ont pu justifier la modification de certains prix. Inutile d'ajouter | qu'il s'agit de baisse sur toute la ligne. Aucune valeur n'a été l'objet d'une attention par ticulière.

Comme on vient de le voir par ce bref exposé, la semaine qui vient de s'écouler a été l'une des plus dépourvues d'intérêt de la saison. Elle ne se distingue en rien des séances d'été, sinoni par une chute assez brusque des cours. L'inactivité en est arrivée à tel point que, si nous ne nous trouvions aux abords de l'hiver, la plupart retourneraient en villégiature.

FLUCTUATIONS DE LA Ors Si nos agents de change n'ont pas à se féliciter du nombre de courtages qu'ils ont en raissés, les détenteurs de titres n'ont pas da vantage & se louer de la tenue de leur portefeuille. La plupart des valeurs abordées ont encore cédé sous le poids des offres et celles qui n'ont pas subi de dépression le doivent en général à une heureuse abstention des por teurs. Sur une soixantaine de titres officielle ment cotés à notre bourse, 31 sont en baisse et 5 seulement en hausse, les autres demeurant stationnaires aux cours de vendredi passé.

p.hi: Parmi les fléchissements les plus'accentas, on constate 15/32 de perte en National Bank, | 25 franes en jouissances Eaux du Caire, 1 li vre en Béhérs, 10 franes en Dividendes Bière d'Alexandrie, 2 livres en Société de Pressage, 1/2 livre en Nungovich Hotels, 7 franos en Dividendes Tramways d'Alexandrie et 1/4 en Ramleh, Dairs et fondateur United.

div.p: L'Anglo American Nile recule de 1 8, l'Agricole, la Land Bank, l'Urbaine, la fondateur Comptoir, la Building Lands, l'Union Foncière et le Crédit Franco-Egyptien de 1/16, la Delta Land de 6/82, l'action Comptoir de 3/32, les Estates et la Levant de 1/32, Pobligation an| cienne Crédit Foncier et la Cassa di Sconto de 2 fr. 50, rObligation nouvelle Crédit Foncier de 2 franes, les Privilégiées Tramways d'Alexandrie de 1 ft. 60, les Sueteries de 11 frane, les Markets et la Port Baid Salt de 6 pence, les Cotton Mills et la Salt and Soda de 3 pence.

Il n'y a en hausse, d'ailleurs insignifiante, que la Spinning de 1/32, les Dividendes Bière du Caire et les Lots Tares de 1 frano, l'Ordinary Khedivial Mail de 4 pence 1/2, et la Banque d'Orient de 50 centimes. No: VALEURS SUR LES MARCHES EUROPRENS.

Au Stock Exchange, la Daira et l'Agricole rétrogradent de 1/4, la Delta Light de 1 8 et la National Bank de 1/2. A Paris, nos titres, si l'on en excepte une réaction de 2 fr. 50 en Crédit Franco-Egyptien, n'accusent pas de variations appréciables. Les fonds d'État qui nous intéressent sont soutenus ; le Consolide est ferme à 89 1/8 et le Rente gagne même 25 points à 95,15.

LA SITUATION MONETARE Pour diminuer la famine d'or qui sévit tos Etats-Unis, le Gouvernement est en train d'émettre pour 10 millions de livres de bons de Panams; si c'est nécessaire, il en émettra jus qu'à concurrence de 20 millions pendant une année. Ces bons porteront afriteret de 9% et

seront remboursables au bout de dix ans ay 1 gró de l'Etat. Les oertificats du Trésor porte ront an intérêt de 8% Les chefs de Congres s'occupent en ce moment d'un système de circulation monétaire de nature faire face tous les besoins. Par l'effet que ces mesures auxiliaire ont produit sur le marché, il est
ident pe population commence à se rassurer.
e Mabretenia pati d'Angleterre pour New Work pris environ 2 millions sterling en or et le 19, tillion / était encore retenu pour la même destination. De plus des agents amé
ricains conduisent d'actives négociations à | Paris enfin tobtenir des envois d'or directs
pour Pathérique. bes financiers etnéricains dottle imprudences nous ont valu la crise mutuelle etter bent, comme on le toit à Temepaier tarefaction de toren en jetant en

sur tomatche. Ilfsat espérer que ce moyen reine Yatheter xux banques Por retiré par les particuliers. Oneralne des retraite & 750 millions de frumos. Lerexportations Por d'Barope dhe provoquer relevement universel de
escompte a des maux quiimposent de tourds serificerer bommerce et u vindustrie, sauf en Pratie ou lbh 'pa Toster 14%

La Banque d'angteterre, v'il faut en croire les légrammes ne tarderit pas à porter son taex decompte 8 % et en Allemagne, si la pénurie monétaires descontne, on s'attend d'an toment a 'etre a une erise financière sigue. Toujouts 'après les dépeches, les étrangers partent en masse de New York pour l'Europe od la vie est moins chère.

Pour le moment des taux sont sans change went 14%* Paris, 7 % à Londres et 7 1/2 % *Berlin. En Angleterre le taux privé augmente de 1/8 à 6 7/8. Quant à la reorve de la Ban. que d'Angleterre, elle ne diminue que de 1 3/4 % 8 38 3/4, contre 40 1/2 % vendredi dernier.

LA ORTSR ROYPTIENNE Les comités de notre bourse s'occupent de modifications à introduire dans le règlement du marché a terme pour le rendre plus acces. sible au public. Il s'agirait particulièrement de ne plus imposer aux agenta l'obligation de déposer eu main du Comité ls marge fixée, étant donné que les compensations hebdoma daire et extraordinaire constituent un acte de telle détense que le dépôt d'une marge est inutile.

Dans le courant de la semaine il a été vendu aux enchères publiques 225 Investment *'8/8, 30 National Bank à 19 15/16, et 300 Cassa di Sconto à 43 franes. On a remarqué cette fois encore que les prix sit.si obtenus sont supérieurs à ceux pratiqués le jour même dans la corbeille. La semaine prochaine on venidra aux enchères 233 Obligations anciennes Crédit Foncier et 126 nouvelles, 2 Banque Nationale de Grèce 1904, 1/4 Ville de Paris 1871, 35 Commereial and Industrial Land, 25 Splendid Hotels, 100 New Egyptian wciennes et 50 nouvelles, 50 Banque d'Athènes, 25 Salt and Sods, 50 Estates, 100 Cotton Mills, 50 Port Said Salt, 50 Levant, 100 Spinning, 25 actions Allotment et 50 fondateurs, "50 Or. dinary Khedivial Mail, 50 Delta Land, 25 Crédit Franco-Bgyptien, 5 fondateurs United, 75 Hooker, 20 Building Lands, et 2 Salt and Soda nouvelles

A ce propos · les tribunaux vont avoir à se prononcer sur une question qui intéresse au plus haut point tous les possesseurs de dossiers avec marge. It s'agit de savoir si un éta blissement a le droit de liquider le compte d'un client dont la marge lui sert de garantie. Un établissement qui a oru pouvoir agir de la sorte se prévaut de ce que la marge constitue un gage, tandis que le client soutient que pour le gage un écrit est indispensable. L'é. tablissement de crédit fait également valoir que dans la période critique actuelle, si les maison qui avance n'avait pas faculté de li quider ses comptes, elle serait acoulée à la faillite. On attend impatiem "nent la sentence du tribunal.

Un groupe d'actionnaires de la New-Egyptian Co., se sont réunis en vue d'une setion collective pour exiger officiellement et au plus tøt du conseil d'Administration l'exposé de la situation actuelle de la société.

Deux procés ont été plaides ces jours-ci au consulat d'Angleterre contre la Bourse and Banking. Le juge consulaire a prononcé que les administrateurs de cette société n'avaient aucun droit de faire signer des formules arbitraires pour la délivraison des titres et il a condamné le conseil d'administration à livrer les titres ou leur contrevaleur, ainsi qu'aux frais. En ce qui concerne la nomination d'un liquidateur officiel en remplacement de M. A Nahman, le juge s'est déclaré compétent. L'avocat de la société qui contestait la juridiction a fait appel d e dernier jugement et l'affaire viendra à la prochaine session de la Cour supreme.

are "Stock Markets and How to Profit by Them"; "Theory of Successful Speculation"; "How to start an Account" ; "The Advantages of 'Call Options'"; "Contangoing Mining and Industrial Securities" ; "How to Invest in Mines"; "American Rails, with Points for Operators in Yankees"; "The Purchase of Investment Securities by Instalments" ; "General Principles for Investors" ; "Rules for Investors in Mines"; "General Principles for Speculators"; "Stock Exchange Terms," being a glossary for Market Operators; "Stock Exchange Parlance"; "Insurance, as a Means of Making, Raising, and Saving Money," and "Colonial Building Land: Its Great Possibilities."

NOTES BT CRITIQUES
Le Caire, Vendredi 22 Novembre. Le taux de l'escompte libre Londres es renseigne invarié à 6 7/8 pour cent.

As Stock-Exchange, le Consolidé anglais haussé hier de 1/4 à 821/4. L'Unifiée est resté inchangée & 99 1/4. La National Bank a flech de 14 a 19 3/4. La Daira a été ferme à 12 1/4 L'Agricole a rétrogradé de 1/8 à 7 3/4 et le Delta Light également de 1/8 à 9 3/4.
A Paris, le Crédit Foncier Egyptien a gagn 1 franc à 679, la Banque d'Athènes 1 fran à 109 et les Lots Turcs 1 frane i 165.

Ici, notre marché, qui ne peut chercher son inspiration ailleurs qu'à Londres, & ressent d'une façon plus marquée qu'à l'ordinaire réperoussion de la mauvaise tenue du group, égyptien là bas. Le découragement s'est encor accentué, et se complique en plus d'incessante besoins d'argent qui obligent certains à liqui der aux prix de famine actuels.

Comme bien l'on pense, ceux qui n'y sont pas obligés, se gardent bien de vendre et pré fèrent avec raison courir les chances d'une renaissance financière de l'Egypte. De sorte que l'on peut considérer les cours pratiques depuis quelque temps somme ne donnant pas une physionomie exacte de la situation, car les vendeurs pris à la gorge passent par ou les acheteurs le veulent. Le mieux est encore d'at tendre que les disponibilités reviennent et que l'Europe se ressaisisse ; les taux d'intérêt bais. sant, l'Egypte verra les capitaux étrangers re chercher des placements chez elle parce que plus rémunérateurs et de toute sécurité.
Parmi les Etablissements de Crédit, la Na tional Bank s'inscrit à 19 13/16 sans affaires. La Banque d'Abyssinie reprend son cours de 4. La Cassa di Sconto fléchit à 42-43.

Les Jouissances Eaux du Caire haussent de 7 franos 162. LA Dairs Sanieh accentue son recul à 12 3/8. Les obligations anciennes da Crédit Foncier Egyptien se tassent à 286 et les nouvelles à 251. La privilégiée Béhéra se raffermit à 4 1/16. L'Allotment fondateur tetombe à P.T. 45. L'Union foncière est dépré. ciée à 4 1/4-3,8. La Compagnie Immobilière recule à 285-289. Les Entreprises Immobilières et Travaux sont demandées à 0 7/8-15/16; les fondateurs s'inscrivent á 20. Les Suere. ries et Raffinerie d'Egypte se relèvent à 34
Dans le groupe des Hotels, les Baebler baissent à 4 11/16, les fondateurs National Ho tels à P. T. 15 et les fondateurs Excelsior à 03/16. .

Parmi les petites valeurs, la Delta Land mollit à 1 3/16-1/4. La New-Egyptian est lourde à 9/3. Les Estates faiblissent à 03/87/16, de même que l'United Land à 0 3/16-1/4 et les Ghézireh Mansions à 0 3/16-1/4. L'Ordinary Khedivial Mail remonte à 21/3.
Le marché des valeurs étant fermé le samedi, le prochain numéro de notre cireulaire ne pa raltra que le lundi 25 Noyembre courant

Les statistiques da "Board of Trade" relativement aux importations et aux exportations prouvent que les arrivages d'or ont été particulièrement grands pendant le mois d'Octobre. Ils représentent un montant de $ 4,228,000, contre 3,285,000 en Octobre 1906 e £2,316,000 en 1905. C'est grâce à deux envois de l'Afrique du Sud s'élevant à £3,292,000, que l'on doit l'importance du montant atteint. De l'Afrique Occidentale il a été importé £ 178,000 et de l'Australie £ 229,000. Les exportations ont eu également une importance plus grande, quoique les retraits d'or pour compte américain n'entrent que pour une proportion modérée en ligne de compte. En tout, il a été embarqué £ 5,800,000 or, contre £ 8,857,000 en 1906 et £8,016,000 on 1905. Le chiffre important de l'année dernière provient de la forte demande pour l'Egypte et l'Amérique. En Octobre il a été exports £ 2,255,000 pour l'Egypte et £ 1,751,000 pour la France, tandis que pour l'Allemagne, les Etats-Unis et l'Italie les exportations ne dépassent pas £ 500,000. La grande demande pour l'Amérique ne s'est produite que ce mois ei et les chiffres de Novembre prendront une grande importance. Pendant les 10 premiers mois de l'année il a été importé Latg. 38,980,000 et exports Latg. 30,785,000 ; un montant de 7 millions est donc resté dans le pays, mais la graņde partie aura quitté le sol britannique ce mois-ci.

div.head: NEW KHEDIVIAL HOTEL, ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: First-class Hotel. Situated in Rosetta Avenue, the finest quarter in the Town. Two mintes from Railway Station. Close to Conservatory and the Opera House. Lift. Electric Light Throughout. Perfect Sanitary Arrangements. Magnificent Ball, Reception, Reading, and Music Rooms. Bar and Smoking Room.
HENRI CHAMOULLEAU, Proprietor.
45 FINE TERRACE ON THE AVENUE. - SPLENDID GARDEN. - OMNIBUS MEET ALL TRAINS AND STEAMERS. 28-26

TENNIS BALLS FRESH SUPPLY WEEKLY.
BOOTS & SHOES.
All the newest shapes in the best English makes:—
BUCKSKIN TENNIS BOOT AT £1 A SPECIALITY.
Owing to the increased business in this Department a new Showroom has been fitted up where better attention can be given to Customers.
CLOTHS: The largest Stock in Egypt of Cloths of the best British Manufacture : TROPICAL TWEEDS, FLANNELS, DRILLS, & c., & c
All garments cut by experienced English cutters. Fit and style guaranteed.
GENTS' OUTFITTING: The newest Shades in Crepe de Chene Ties. Cellular, Oxford, Zephyr Shirts and Pyjamas in great variety.
Special Attention paid to Shirts Made to Measure.
HOSIERY AND UNDERCLOTHING IN THE BEST MAKES.
PANAMA, STRAW, & FELT HATS CORK & PITH HELMETS. CAPS.

SOAP, PERFUMERY, RUBBER SPONGES, BRUSHES, STUDS, MIRRORS (Hand & Shaving) FOUNTAIN PENS, &c., &c.

div.head: Commercial & Financial Supplement of the "Egyptian Gazette. "
div.p: The Commercial and Financial Supplement of the "Egyptian Gazette" is published at midday every Saturday in time for the Austrian Lloyd's mail. The supplement contains exhaustive and important reviews of the cotton, cotton seed, and stock and share markets, with all the latest statistics up to the evening of the preceding day, complete tabular forms of the various market fluctuations, and the copies of the official telegrams of the Liverpool Cotton Association, etc., etc. Subscription for one year P.T. 100 (inclusive of postage in Egypt for abroad the postage is P.T. 10 extra). For Further particulars apply to the Manager the "Egyptian Gazette."
